bottom_line: Most slopes are adjusting to the ongoing dry spell, but not all terrain has fully stabilized. Expect stubborn wind slabs on recently drifted slopes, and give yourself a cautious margin on the shady side of the compass near and above treeline where a low-probability persistent slab could still break deeper and wider.  The safest and highest quality riding is in wind-protected terrain at lower elevations.

problems.details: A large persistent slab on a wind-loaded slope near Crystal Peak that likely ran around January 10th during a previous wind event.

In this skier-triggered wind slab from last week, you can see where the slab formed on the lee or cross-loaded side of the subtle ridge line. To the lookers' right and left of the slab, you can see wind erosion with some raised tracks.

bottom_line: There are two types of slab avalanches you can encounter today. Both primarily exist on the northern half of the compass. The more likely problem to encounter is small, hard slabs that formed at all elevations on the lee sides of terrain features. These old wind slabs are responsible for multiple skier-triggered avalanches over the last several days. The more significant, but less likely to trigger avalanche problem would be a slab avalanche releasing 1.5 to 3 feet deep on old, persistent weak layers. You can reduce your exposure to these avalanche problems by riding in wind-sheltered terrain, where you will also find the best snow quality for skiing and riding.

In this avalanche example, you can see where the slab formed on the lee or cross-loaded side of the subtle ridge line. To the lookers' right and left of the slab, you can see wind erosion with some raised tracks.

bottom_line: An ongoing northerly wind event is responsible for multiple human-triggered wind slabs at all elevations. These small slabs have typically formed on cross-loaded terrain features on the northern half of the compass. In one case, a triggered wind slab stepped down to the deeper and more concerning persistent slab avalanche problem. The best snow quality can currently be found in wind-sheltered areas, where you can avoid those hard slabs created by the wind. You can also reduce your exposure to the larger persistent slab avalanche problem by choosing lower slope angles or terrain below about 10,500ft in elevation.
